awd_titl_txt: Dimensions:  Collaborative Research:  An Interdisciplinary Study of Hyperdiverse Fungal Endophytes and Their Function in Boreal Forests
awd_abstract_narration:
As major sources of ecological and evolutionary innovation, symbioses drive genome evolution, ecological diversification, and speciation - and thus shape all dimensions of the diversity of life.  The goal of this study is to examine the taxonomic, genetic, and functional diversity of endophytes, one of Earth's most prevalent, but least-understood, groups of symbionts.  Endophytic fungi are found within healthy above-ground tissues of all plants (and in lichens as "endolichenic fungi"), including crop- and forage plants, and peak in their phylogenetic diversity in boreal forests, an imperiled ecosystem of immense global importance.  This interdisciplinary study will develop a novel biodiversity informatics pipeline to discover, evaluate, and describe new species of boreal endophytes at multiple spatial and phylogenetic scales around the circumboreal belt.  Culture-based and culture-free surveys will yield the largest sample of endophytic fungi to date, setting the stage for testing novel hypotheses regarding the evolution of ecological modes in the Ascomycota, the most species-rich fungal phylum; developing new model systems for evaluating, for the first time, the functional diversity of endophyte communities; and elucidating the genetic mechanisms shaping that diversity, including mobile genetic elements, endohyphal microbial symbionts, and genome evolution.  Data will be managed and released through an integrated system built around the Suite of Nucleotide Analysis Programs (SNAP) and made public through a dedicated web portal, EnDoBiodiversity.org. 

This highly integrative project also seeks to promote diversity in science for high school students, STEM teachers, undergraduate and graduate students, and postdoctoral scholars at scales ranging from local outreach at four universities to widespread international collaboration.  Hosting of international researchers, leadership of international workshops, and development of international symposia will synergize fungal taxonomy and molecular systematics while boosting rates of species descriptions to a level never reached before and fostering novel collaborations in the study of fungal symbionts.  Building and sharing of novel biodiversity informatics tools will be complemented by development and deposition of permanent fungal culture collections and extensive molecular sequence datasets.

por.por_cntn:
Boreal forests rank among the most threatened ecosystems in our rapidly changing world. Fungi that occur in boreal forests can greatly influence plant physiology, growth, defense, and reproduction, and thus are central to forest health, sustainability, and resiliency. However, some important groups of fungi – including fungal endophytes -- remain understudied in these imperiled forests.

Fungal endophytes are fungi that occur within healthy plant tissues such as leaves. They are known from every plant species examined so far. At a global scale, they are thought to be hyperdiverse, though the factors understanding their host affiliations and geographic distributions are not yet well understood. Previous work suggested that endophytes in the boreal biome encompass a tremendous amount of genomic-, symbiotic-, and ecological diversity, but these important symbionts of boreal plants and lichens had not been surveyed previously at a large scale, and the ecological factors shaping their host associations at local, regional, and global scales had not yet been assessed.

The aims of our study were to capture the diversity of endophytic fungi in iconic species of plants and lichens around the circumboreal belt. To do so we conducted field surveys of 20 plant- and lichen species in sites that included western and central Alaska, northwestern and northeastern Canada, the upper peninsula of Michigan, nothern Sweden, and central and far eastern Russia. We completed extensive sampling in Québec, Canada, along environmental gradients that covered the extent of boreal forest from the south to the northern boundary, and along a single latitudinal band that spanned a dversity of rainfall conditions. We linked these datasets with sampling relevant to climate change, edaphic traits, and fire history.

To achieve our aims, endophytes were isolated in culture and host tissue was sampled directly for metagenetic analysis. Focal endophytes were then studied to evaluate their effects on plant health, physiology, and productivity. Our collections included over 16,000 living strains and metagenetic data from over 3000 individual collections of host material. These data and vouchers are available to the public and for future studies.

We used these data to contribute to a collaborative effort to build bioinformatics tools that can accelerate species descriptions for little-known groups. We also shared strains among labs to identify new taxa, sequence their genomes, and address questions ranging from population genomics to enzyme activity. We evaluated for the first time the effects of bacteria that live within these fungi, demonstrating their preeminent role in shaping fungal traits. Overall, by linking environmental data with DNA sequence data ranging from single loci to whole genomes, we have been able to link endophytes to climate, forest productivity, geographic locations, edaphic factors, and host species with a new degree of precision and accuracy. Together these efforts provide the basis for future studies and for integrating fungal symbionts into assessments of, and strategies for, boreal forest conservation.

Each of these activities was undertaken with the specific aims of engaging diverse members of the public, students, and educational institutions in microbial ecology, genetics, genomics, mycology, and systematics. The portion of this project that was based at the Arnold lab at The University of Arizona supported training opportunities for 33 participants, including diverse high school students, undergraduates, graduate students, postdocs, visiting scholars, and K-12 teachers. Our project provided the basis for engaging hundreds of students each year in the classroom, in the field, and in the University of Arizona Gilberson Mycological Herbarium.
